publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 92.38

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
Transcription and translation are based on .

seg.seg: ... in the rays that have gone to the gods and the people, ...
|| Rise up! Go out! Join the instruction of the Buddha! Shake off the army of death, like an elephant (shakes) a bamboo hut! 1. And who in this (instruction pertaining to the) Law
(will not be negligent, he, having left the circle of births,) will go to the end of suffering. 2. || This voice is heard all over the three-thousand-fold world ...
Die Stimme wird in der ganzen dreitausendfachen Welt gehört.
The voice is heard in the whole three-thousand-fold world.
they attach themselves to the great good deeds. Thereupon these rays, having united a second time, (surround the head of?) the Buddha-god Maitreya, the master, (and enter his Uṣṇīṣa)
(Then) Maitreya, the Buddha-god, having called the king Siṃha, says: Get up, get up, my son! || In the Chandakavartana-tune:|| You will surely afterwards
You will certainly appear (in the world) hereafter. (cf 73–74)
(appear in the world) ... as the Tathāgata named Śākyamuni, as a venerable Buddha-god, who has understood all Dharmas. || Then the king Siṃha,
having (joyful) thoughts (like a poor man, who) is pleased by (a treasure), having risen upright from the earth, having, with his both hands in Añjali, worshipped the two feet of Maitreya,

...(is ready) to go from the house. (Thereupon the Buddha god Maitreya, the master), having drawn him (from the house), performs the ordination for him. || Thereupon the king Siṃha, having become a monk, in order to make his observance real with his extinguished happy senses... ///
/// Upon the wish of (Kulmäs O)rś (this book has) been composed by the Vaibhāṣika Āryacandra. In the Maitreyasamiti-Nāṭaka (the twenty-sixth act entitled) Siṃha-vyākaraṇa has come to an end. ||
Then the venerable Buddha-god Maitreya, observing the tasks of Buddha-hood to the very end, (remembers himself) his mother Brahmāvatī, who was reborn among the gods: ( || In the ...-tune: || )

... My father Brahmāyu has been released from the Saṃsāra by me. My (mother) Brahmāvatī is (still) to be released (by me). ... may she wish to be released by me! : 1. || Thereupon the Buddha-god Maitreya...

p.note: This fragment contains the end of the twenty-sixth and the beginning of the twenty-seventh act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; the colophon of act 26 is in line b3. Uy. parallels are MaitrSiŋgim, Leaf 13 = Taf. 88v (for A 258r), and Taf. 185r f. (217) for the end of act XXVI (= MaitrHami 26, Blatt 13v), as well as MaitrHami 27, Blatt 8, 1r for the beginning of act 27. See 204 and 73f.

The Udānavarga verses (Uv IV.37-38) in lines a4-5 are also to be found in b5-6, and are parallel to MaitrSiŋgim Taf. 88 v.1-17. King Simha's future Buddha-hood is prophesied in line 8a here, as in MaitrSiŋgim Blatt 14.

In the TA text here, there is a gap of 4+12 syllables at the beginning of line 8a, containing the end of pāda a, and pāda b of this strophe; there is another gap in b5, which must contain the name of a tune, most likely a strophe of 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7. The tune Chandakavartana in line a7 has the same length and rhythm (cf. 75, fn. 179, 181).

In the colophon a man named Kulmäs Orś is mentioned as the donor or patron of the manuscript. The same name is mentioned in b6. assume that the family of this dignitary were natives of Agni (Yanqi) (see also 263).

Fragment of a manuscript which includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. 64-5). The fragment is badly damaged, only the left half of the leaf remains. The original leaf must have been remarkably long, with about 50 syllables in line 8a. Lines a1-2 and b7-8 are lost.
The fragment contains the end of act 26 with the colophon and the beginning of act 27.
The translation and commentary for this fragment can be found in 73-75.
The tune name has been lost. The meter is 4x12 (5/7).

div.p: Edition133-134; 73f. Siegling's personal copy of p. 133 p. 134.

list.item: a3 /// ·ñ·ktas napeṃsac _k_alk·n_t\ /// a4 /// luneṣiṃ ra_t_a_k\ • _k_arwāṣi waṣtt oki oṅka_l_a_m\ : 1 ku – – – _ṣ _m_a /// a5 /// _k\ • klopi_s\ ākā yäṣ\ : 2 || sām waśeṃ poñcäṃ tri wältse· ārkiśoṣṣaṃ klyo_s_n_a_ṣ_t_a_r\ – – – – – – a6 /// śāwaṃ kāswoneytwaṃ ritwant_r_a _t_m_aṣ to_m\ swāñcenāñä\ wtā_k _k_ampo nāṃtsu_r_a_ṣ\ metra_k_aṃ ptāñ_k_a – – – a7 /// [_t _k_a]ṣṣi siṃheṃ lān_t\ kākku_r_a_ṣ t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ _p_aṣta_m\ _p_aṣtam se || channakanivartnaṃ || tāt ṣakk ats tu tanā – a8 /// śākyamuni ñomā _t_amne wäknā kakmu : āṣānik pu_k _m_arkampalntu _k_arso ptāñ_k_a_t\ : 1 || _t_m_aṣ siṃhe wä_l\ b1 /// yo pā_p_l_antu _p_alsku_m\ tka_n_aṣ kā_k_atku āñcāli tsa_r_anyo met_r_akyāp peṃ wawiṃṣu_r_a_ṣ\ wa_ṣ_t_a_ṣ _l_añclu b2 /// _ṣ\ tsko_r_aṣ wa_s_ampāt ya_ṣ-_aṃ || _t_m_aṣ siṃhe wä_l\ ṣāmaṃ nāṃtsu kaksun_t\ wsokaṃ indrisyo pāpṣune _k·_aṣ· b3 /// rśess ākālā vaibhāṣikyā_p\ āryacandres raritwu maitreyasamiti nāṭkaṃ siṃhavyāka[ra]ṃ – – – b4 /// _k(\) ptāñ_k_a_t\ lyukrā _s_arki puttiśparṣinā_s\ wlesan_t\ wlesmāṃ ñäktasaṃ tatmusāṃ brah·ā – – – – – b5 /// brahmāyu pācar śaśälpu ñi saṃsā_r_a_ṣ\ : t_s_a_l_p_aṣlyi [t]ā – – hmāva·i /// b6 /// ·i-ñi : 1 || _t_m_aṣ metra_k\ ptāñ ///

This fragment contains the end of the twenty-sixth and the beginning of the twenty-seventh act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; the colophon of act 26 is in line b3. Uy. parallels are MaitrSiŋgim, Leaf 13 = Taf. 88v (for A 258r), and Taf. 185r f. ([[Tekin 1980]]: 217) for the end of act XXVI (= MaitrHami 26, Blatt 13v), as well as MaitrHami 27, Blatt 8, 1r for the beginning of act 27. See [[Pinault 1999]]: 204 and [[Geng et al. 2004a]]:73f.

The Udānavarga verses (Uv IV.37-38) in lines a4-5 are also to be found in [[A 354]] b5-6, and are parallel to MaitrSiŋgim Taf. 88 v.1-17. King Simha's future Buddha-hood is prophesied in line 8a here, as in MaitrSiŋgim Blatt 14.

In the TA text here, there is a gap of 4+12 syllables at the beginning of line 8a, containing the end of pāda a, and pāda b of this strophe; there is another gap in b5, which must contain the name of a tune, most likely a strophe of 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7. The tune Chandakavartana in line a7 has the same length and rhythm (cf. [[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 75, fn. 179, 181).

In the colophon a man named Kulmäs Orś is mentioned as the donor or patron of the manuscript. The same name is mentioned in [[A 252]] b6. [[Geng et al. 2004a]] assume that the family of this dignitary were natives of Agni (Yanqi) (see also [[Schmidt KT 2002a]]: 263).

b4-b5. The tune name has been lost. The meter is 4x12 (5/7).

Fragment of a manuscript which includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. [[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 64-5). The fragment is badly damaged, only the left half of the leaf remains. The original leaf must have been remarkably long, with about 50 syllables in line 8a. Lines a1-2 and b7-8 are lost.

The fragment contains the end of act 26 with the colophon and the beginning of act 27.

The translation and commentary for this fragment can be found in [[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 73-75.

[[TochSprR(A)]]: 134 read k·aṣ·, which conflicts with the restoration kn(ä)ssi. If this is indeed a form of [[kän-]], it is likely [[knäṣtär]] or knäṣtr-äṃ. (Siegling restores [[kläṣmune|kl(ä)ṣ(mune)]] in his personal copy.) (BK)


Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a7 You will certainly appear (in the world) hereafter. (cf [[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 73–74) 228

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a5 Die Stimme wird in der ganzen dreitausendfachen Welt gehört. 81, 219


a5: [[Carling, DThTA]]: 31 reads klopis ākā yäṣ (TI)

beginning of b3: supplemented to read ///(kulmäss o)rśess ākālā in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 33 (TI)

a6, towards the end, translation as above, or: “these rays having again formed a circle”, as per [[Carling, DThTA]]: 165? (TI)

the end of b2 reads pāpṣune k(n)äs(si) in [[Carling, DThTA]]: 179 (TI)


I have moved the [[Geng et al. 2004a]] -reference from the parallel-texts-slot to the phil.comm, and added material from [[Pinault 1999]]. Please move and/or delete as appropriate! (TI)

a4-5: reconstruction by parallel lines in [[A 354]] b5-6 - I have marked the parts taken over from there as Unwörter! (TI)

transliteration still as it was, since don't know actual spelling, and to document differences. transcription and translation = Geng et al. (TI)

a7 (phil. comm.): The rhythm of this stanza is 4/4/4, not 5/7. (BK)

a3 /// ·ñ(ä)ktas napeṃsac kälk(o)nt (swāñcenāsaṃ) /// a4 (posāc pälcäs • pritwäs ptāñäkte enäṣluneyaṃ • ptäpsäs wla)luneṣiṃ ratäk • kärwāṣi waṣtt oki oṅkaläm : 1 ku(s ne nu ca)ṣ mä(rkampalṣi enäṣluneyaṃ) a5 (sne ykorñe tāṣ • wawikuräṣ cmolwāṣiṃ sar)k • klopis ākā yäṣ : 2 || sām waśeṃ poñcäṃ tri wältse(ṃ) ārkiśoṣṣaṃ klyosnäṣtär – – – – – – a6 /// śāwaṃ kāswoneyäntwaṃ|kāswoneytwaṃ ritwanträ tmäṣ tom swāñcenāñ wtāk kämpo nāṃtsuräṣ metrakäṃ ptāñkä(t käṣyāp) a7 /// (metrak ptāñkä)t käṣṣi_(TA)|käṣṣi siṃheṃ lānt kākkuräṣ träṅkäṣ päṣtam päṣtam se || chandakanivartnaṃ|channakanivartnaṃ || # tāt ṣakk ats tu ; tanā särki|(sä|rki) a8 ; %4 #1a %12 /// (:) #1b śākyamuni ; ñomā tämne ; wäknā kakmu : #1c āṣānik puk ; märkampalntu ; kärso ptāñkät : 1 || #1d tmäṣ siṃhe wäl b1 /// yo pāpläntu pälskum tkanäṣ kākätku āñcāli tsaränyo meträkyāp peṃ wawiṃṣuräṣ waṣtäṣ läñcluneyac|läñclu|(neyac) b2 (ārwar mäskatär) /// (waṣtä)ṣ tskoräṣ wasämpāt yaṣ-äṃ || tmäṣ siṃhe wäl ṣāmaṃ nāṃtsu kaksunt wsokaṃ indrisyo pāpṣune k(n)äs(si) b3 /// (säs postäk kulmäs orśes|o)rśess ākālā vaibhāṣikyāp āryacandres raritwu maitreyasamiti nāṭkaṃ siṃhavyākaraṃ (ñomā wikiṣäkpint|wi|kiṣäkpint) b4 /// (nipāt ār || tmäṣ āṣānik metra)k ptāñkät lyukrā särki puttiśparṣinās wlesant wlesmāṃ ñäktasaṃ tatmusāṃ brah(m)ā(vati mācrac) – – b5 /// # brahmāyu pācar ; śaśälpu ñi , saṃsāräṣ : #1b tsälpäṣlyi tā(ṣ-ñi ; bra)hmāva(t)i , (mācar) /// %1 #1c b6 %9 /// , (tsälp)i-ñi : 1 || #1d tmäṣ metrak ptāñ(kät) ///

a3 ... in the rays that have gone to the gods and the people, ... a4 || Rise up! Go out! Join the instruction of the Buddha! Shake off the army of death, like an elephant (shakes) a bamboo hut! 1. And who in this (instruction pertaining to the) Law a5 (will not be negligent, he, having left the circle of births,) will go to the end of suffering. 2. || This voice is heard all over the three-thousand-fold world ... a6 they attach themselves to the great good deeds. Thereupon these rays, having united a second time, (surround the head of?) the Buddha-god Maitreya, the master, (and enter his Uṣṇīṣa) a7 (Then) Maitreya, the Buddha-god, having called the king Siṃha, says: Get up, get up, my son! || In the Chandakavartana-tune:|| You will surely afterwards a8 (appear in the world) ... as the Tathāgata named Śākyamuni, as a venerable Buddha-god, who has understood all Dharmas. || Then the king Siṃha, b1 having (joyful) thoughts (like a poor man, who) is pleased by (a treasure), having risen upright from the earth, having, with his both hands in Añjali, worshipped the two feet of Maitreya, b2 ...(is ready) to go from the house. (Thereupon the Buddha god Maitreya, the master), having drawn him (from the house), performs the ordination for him. || Thereupon the king Siṃha, having become a monk, in order to make his observance real with his extinguished happy senses... /// b3 /// Upon the wish of (Kulmäs O)rś (this book has) been composed by the Vaibhāṣika Āryacandra. In the Maitreyasamiti-Nāṭaka (the twenty-sixth act entitled) Siṃha-vyākaraṇa has come to an end. || b4 Then the venerable Buddha-god Maitreya, observing the tasks of Buddha-hood to the very end, (remembers himself) his mother Brahmāvatī, who was reborn among the gods: ( || In the ...-tune: || ) b5 ... My father Brahmāyu has been released from the Saṃsāra by me. My (mother) Brahmāvatī is (still) to be released (by me). ... may she wish to be released by me! : 1. || Thereupon the Buddha-god Maitreya...

div.p: <citedRange>134</citedRange></bibl> read <hi>k·<hi rend="underline">a</hi>ṣ·</hi>, which conflicts with the restoration <hi>kn(ä)ssi</hi>. If this is indeed a form of <w lemma="kän-"/>, it is likely <w lemma="knäṣtär"/> or <hi>knäṣtr-äṃ</hi>. (Siegling restores [[kläṣmune|kl(ä)ṣ(mune)]] in his <ref target="./images/TS_Siegling/TS_Siegling_Page_134.png">personal copy</ref>.) (BK)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a5"/>: <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>31</citedRange></bibl> reads <hi>klopis ākā yäṣ</hi> (TI) </p><p> beginning of <ref type="ms" target="__b3"/>: supplemented to read <hi>///(kulmäss o)rśess ākālā</hi> in <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>33</citedRange></bibl> (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a6"/>, towards the end, translation as above, or: “these rays <b>having again formed</b> a circle”, as per <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>165</citedRange></bibl>? (TI)</p><p>the end of <ref type="ms" target="__b2"/> reads <hi>pāpṣune k(n)äs(si)</hi> in <bibl><title corresp="ref:carlingetal2009"/><citedRange>179</citedRange></bibl> (TI)</p><p>I have moved the <bibl><title corresp="ref:gengetal2004a"/></bibl> -reference from the parallel-texts-slot to the phil.comm, and added material from <bibl><title corresp="ref:pinault1999"/></bibl>. Please move and/or delete as appropriate! (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a4-5"/>: reconstruction by parallel lines in <ref type="ms" target="txt:m-a354"/> b5-6 - I have marked the parts taken over from there as Unwörter! (TI)</p><p>transliteration still as it was, since don't know actual spelling, and to document differences. transcription and translation = Geng et al. (TI)</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a7"/> (phil. comm.): The rhythm of this stanza is 4/4/4, not 5/7. (BK)</p></project_comment>
